avalancheActivity.comment: Avalanche danger above 2200 m is considerable, below that altitude danger is moderate. Fresh drifts can trigger a medium slab by 1 person. Danger zones occur esp. in steep ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in gullies and bowls. Frequency and size of danger zones increase with ascending altitude and during the course of the day. Activities in outlying terrain demand experience in assessing avalanche dangers on-site. Isolated glide-snow avalanches are possible. Avoid zones below glide-cracks. In case of extended bright intervals, small loose-snow avalanches are possible.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Trigger-prone snowdrifts due to fresh snow + winds

avalancheProblems.comment: steep ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities, in gullies and bowls

snowpackStructure.comment: Over the last 24 hours in northern regions there has been 35 cm of fresh snow registered, in Lechquellen 25-30 cm, in Verwall 15 cm, and in the southern Rätikon-Silvretta region 25 cm. Amid winds from the northwest, the fresh snow was transported. In the new drifts are weak layers (often with graupel). Prior to the snowfall the slopes were bare up to intermediate altitudes. The fresh snow lies on bare ground or a moist snowpack and is well bonded. The snowpack is often wet down to the ground, and tends towards gliding downhill as a mass. Small glide-snow avalanches are being observed on slopes which before were bare of snow.

tendency.comment: Until the end of the week, fresh snow will arrive in several bouts, focus in NW barrier cloud regions between Verwall, Arlberg and Bregenzerwald. The avalanche situation will remain tense.

weatherForecast.comment: Nocturnal hours: heavily overcast skies, light-to-moderate snow showers. Thursday daytime: Wintery! Cold April weather will continue, graupel and snow showers will pass through, focus in the barrier cloud regions between Arlberg and Bregenzerwald mountains. At 2000 m: -10 to -6 degrees. Light northerly winds.

avalancheActivity.comment: Avalanche danger above 2000 m is considerable, below that altitude danger is moderate. Fresh snow and drifts are prone to triggering. Medium avalanches can be triggered by 1 person. Snowdrift accumulations lie deposited in steep ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in gullies and bowls. Backcountry undertakings require experience in assessing dangers on-site. Isolated glide-snow avalanches are still possible. Avoid zones below glide cracks. In case of extended bright intervals, small loose-snow avalanches can trigger naturally.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh snow and drifts are prone to triggering

avalancheProblems.comment: fresh snow and drifts remain trigger-prone

The fresh snow lies on bare ground or a moist snowpack and is well bonded. The snowpack is often wet down to the ground, and tends towards gliding downhill as a mass. Small glide-snow avalanches are being observed on slopes which before were bare of snow.

Light northerly winds.

Small-to-medium avalanches can be triggered by 1 person. Danger zones occur esp. in steep ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in gullies and bowls. Frequency and size of danger zones increase with ascending altitude and during the course of the day. Activities in outlying terrain demand experience in assessing avalanche dangers on-site. Isolated glide-snow avalanches are possible. Avoid zones below glide-cracks. In case of extended bright intervals, small loose-snow avalanches are possible.
